data.text: Electronic Shifting for Gravel Touring

Im thinking about upgrading my gravel bike, and drivetrain, this fall to electric shifting (1x). I love E-tap on my road bike, but would like to get opinions (good and bad) on electric shifting for gravel. I used mechanical shifting at Unbound and no issues. Thanks in advance. Keep on grinding…
I have Di2 on my gravel bike and have for 2 years, AXS GX on my MTB for the last several months. Both work great and I would not willingly go back to mechanical
data.author: Drew Downing

data.text: AXS is great for gravel.
data.author: Eric Donnell

data.text: It works as well on gravel as on the road. The 2x ‘wide’ gives great range and close spacing.
data.author: John Knapp

data.text: Agree. I live in an extremely hilly area. Just got tired of constantly shifting from small to big ring in the front. Dropped my chain more than a few times.
data.author: Rick Giolito

data.text: I just upgraded from mechanical 2x Shimano GRX to 1x SRAM GX Eagle AXS eTap. I’ll never go back.
data.author: Rick Giolito

data.text: what handlebar and shifter setup do you have?
data.author: Raphael K Koikoi

data.text: I’m looking at the Wxpert or Pro Crux, both have electronic shifting. I have to check the specs. I’m riding Force on my road bike and love it, but was concerned about gravel. Thanks for the thoughts.
data.author: Stephen Patrick

data.text: so new groupset - RD, cassette, shifters, chain?. Same callipers? Just curious what the swap cost for the parts. thanks
data.author: Chris Summers

data.text: SRAM Rival eTap AXS Shift/Hydraulic Disc Brake & Whiskey Parts Co. No. 7 drop bar
data.author: Rick Giolito

data.text: Everything has to be changed. Only works with the SRAM Rival eTap AXS Shift/Hydraulic Disc Brake L/R I’m guessing parts were around $1500-$1600 not including the White Industries cranks. Then of course you have to upgrade the wheels, headset & bottom bracket (actually you don’t but I did). Everything except the handlebars was changed out from a stock All City Cosmic Stallion Shimano GRX 2x11.
data.author: Rick Giolito

data.text: thanks. Asking as I have the same bike I think. 2018 AC Cosmic Stallion. Mine is rival 22. I changed the crank to 46/30 and went up to a 34 tooth rear and 650b carbon wheels. It works 'pretty' well but the front shifting isn't great. Its become my go-to bike for pretty much everything. Love the crank BTW. I just picked up a retro WI triple for a vintage MTB.

data.text: I see the RedShift stem!! Nice.

data.text: I’m smitten with All City. Super cool rig, bro. We sell some steel at the LBS where I work. Do you have the dropper post?

data.text: No dropper post. I don’t usually get that agressive.
data.author: Rick Giolito

data.text: Yes, I’d sometimes miss shifts on steep uphill chunky gravel due to exhaustion or pure stupidity. The 1x has solved that problem.
data.author: Rick Giolito

data.text: They have an upgrade kit for $600...has the r/d and a bar mounted controller. Of course you won't be able to shift with your lever...but it's a much cheaper way to get into E-shifting if someone wanted to go that route or rides flatbar.
data.author: Chad Ashton

data.text: Yes, I had to order the left & right eTap shifters for my drop bars seperately at $211.00 for each side. The set comes with flat bar shifters. Would be $422.00 cheaper had I gone with the flat bars.
data.author: Rick Giolito

data.text: gotcha. We have a few in the store that have dropper posts, so was wondering is that was common with All City gravel rigs. Interesting nuance.

data.text: I have a Kinekt Suspension seatpost that I cannot live without so dropper post not possible.
